contextId.information: The nominal adjective "poor" can be stated as an adjective. AT: "no poor people" or "no one who is poor" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
The nominal adjective "the wise" can be translated as an adjective. AT: "a wise person" or "wise people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])

The nominal adjective "the evil" can be translated as an adjective. AT: "you must remove from among the Israelites the person who does this evil thing" or "you must execute this evil person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
contextId.quote: you will put away the evil from Israel

contextId.information: The adjective "evil" can be translated as a noun phrase. AT: "and you must remove from among the Israelites the person who does this evil thing" or "and you must execute this evil person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
contextId.quote: and you will remove the evil from among you

contextId.information: These nominal adjectives can be translated as nouns. Because the land was usually dry and the people needed rain so their crops would grow, these words are metaphors for "living ... dead" or "good ... bad."  AT: "wet things ... dry things" or "good people ... bad people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
